column49: - Talk-aloud recording doing a particular tasks - Structured interview

column47: It goes without saying that direct contact with end users is always beneficial for me as a UX Designer / business analyst. However, in most projects (designing and building applications for customers) we have little or no access to actual end users, and rely mostly on the expertise of other domain experts provided by the customer. The most typical contact we have with end users is conducting interviews over voice or video call, sometimes in combination with remote observation of usage. This lack of continuous direct contact regularly leads to bad design desicions simply due to insufifficent information on user needs.

column49: Dev UX testing for a new API: We'll ask users to use an API that has not yet been released and ask them to log challenges they had with that.
Developer experience tests: a developer that doesn't know the API is asked to do some seemingly basic tasks with the API.

column22: Vaadin Meetup presentations, showing their apps made with Vaadin

column47: - Vaadin spring addon.  - Binder API localization discussions.

column49: UX/DX testing sessions. As a spectator.
end user or developer testing of a new sofware component or UI element

column47: Generally, the client feels that either they are so knowledgeable about their users that they do not need to gather further information from them, or they plan to do so themselves and are not interested in involving Vaadin in that process.  They may simply not be accustomed to relying on others (us) to communicate with end users, or they may be concerned about the cost of involving us.  Most often, the issue is quickly dismissed by the client when raised.  Deadlines and budget constraints are often cited.

column49: Usability testing for the UI components we develop, testing how easy it is to accomplish the specified tasks/use cases we are testing.
Usability testing of the APIs of our software products, usually done before shipping a bigger set of new APIs that work together to accomplish a set of related use cases.
